newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: CRICKET-ZIMBABWE HANG ON FOR A DRAW.
newsitem.headline: CRICKET-ZIMBABWE HANG ON FOR A DRAW.

text.p: Stubborn batting by
middle-order men Andy Flower and Guy Whittal enabled Zimbabwe to
escape with a draw on Monday in the opening test against
Pakistan.
Zimbabwe, needing 178 to wipe out their first innings
deficit, had faced defeat after being reduced to 177 for five.
But Pakistan reckoned without Flower and Whittal, who
refused to budge. Flower stuck 204 minutes for his 18 and
Whittal remained 130 for 32.
The pair helped Zimbabwe to a total of 241 for seven.
A third wicket stand of 84 by Grant Flower and David
Houghton had boosted Zimbabwe from 40 for two to 124 for three
but once they were parted the scoring slowed.
Flower made 46 and Houghton 65, including 11 fours. Both
fell to off-spinner Saqlain Mushtaq, who finished with four for
Pakistan's bowling was depleted by the absence of paceman
Wasim Akram in the crucial final session. He crashed into an
advertising board when chasing a ball and limped out of the
match.
Akram had the consolation of the man-of-the-match award for
his career-best 257 not out.
Zimbabwe captain Alistair Campbell said: "The draw was a
fair result after we had held the upper hand on the second day.
We had a few hiccups but managed to hold on in the end."
Both the teams now travel to Faisalabad for the decisive
second test starting on Thursday.
